text: [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, 1L takeaways 02-04/10/2015. - Deep amber-russet pour, orange shine. the subtle/subdued nose of dry breadcrust (Landbrot) smeared with bee honey and a hint of near-saazy spicy hops does not yet fully betray the malty riches that lie beneath: dry, satisfying Landbrot, honey and a herbal, sagey twist - subdued savouriness, leaving the minerals and smoke to be supplied by the Pressack and multiple sausage Brotzeit...Slightly buttery finish and minimal whiffs of ethanol, despite the clear pour.
Würziger, leicht karamelliger Antrunk. Geringe Süße, spritzig, leichte Herbe ab dem Mittelteil. Süffig getreidiger Abgang, malzig, vielleicht etwas zu trocken. 12/12/12/10//12

Draught at Posterer, November 2012: Ruddy orange. Sticky white halo of foam. Supremely delicate and soft nose of spice cake, wooden hops (sassafras, earth), apricot marmalade, cookie, toasted bread, and a touch of honeysuckle. Initially firm with a healthy dose of minerals and crisp cookie backed with herbaceous, fennel-tinged hop bitterness and fluffy spicy cake. Pronounced yeasty bite coincides beautifully with the snappy mineral scrubbing action. Copious amounts of bouncy and juicy melanoidin fills the palate with appealing massaging textures and beautify the slick and zesty marmalade lusciousness. Looming caramelized sugar and candied pecan "grip" beneath the softer malt. Pervasively honeyish. Finishes well-attenuated yet earthy and fully malty with herbal hop echoes to induce appetite and temper the sugars. After spending some time with the style, zoiglbier can often seem a bit redundant, as the variability  from to the next tends to be negligible. That said, I would be a happy man if this were my everyday quaffer. Might be a bit straightforward, but its yet another clean and slammable example with exemplary malt structure.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: NOV 22, 2014 draft at Zum Posterer in Windischeschenbach hazed honey amber body with a fine and soft white head. rich and creamy mouthfeel, full-bodied with frothy full carbonation.  toasty biscuit pilsner malt with spicy peppercorns and mildly musty / pungent yeast, turning to shades of mushroom, soil and wood, then to minerals and seasalt, then to fresh, juicy, pulpy nectar and toffee crackers / sugar-glazed almond pastries. one of the gems from this leg in zoigl land.
From Tap in the Zoiglstube. It smells malty, bitter. It tastes malty-sweet, a little bit bitter. A more sweet Zoigl. 11/10/11/10/-/11

on tap at posterer, in 09 and 10 on the way to neuhaus zoiglfest and on the way back. ligtly hazed light amber with a sturdy head; very clean and grassy, lightly chalky, plenty of bitterness if you look for it; extremely drinkable

(draught) pours a very hazy deep amber colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of grass, chewy pale malts, light sweet spices and a hint of cashew nuts. flavour is quite grainy, with a mellow nutty finish. medium-bodied with average carbonation.
Cloudy amber with large off white creamy head. Malty nose with fruity and caramel notes. Malty flavor with caramel, floral hops and fruity hints. Soft mouthfeel. Smooth and clean.

Tap. Cloudy orange, champagne bubbles, big fluffy offwhite head. Light peachy, citric hoppy aroma. Full fruity entry, minerals take over, cranberries, grassy, citric balance. Chewy, yet dancing on the palate.  Wonderfull moreish beer.
Tap at Zoiglhaus.  Milky malt aroma.  Cloudy amber color with a moderate head.  Creamy malt and moderately bitter grassy hops flavor.  Nice body.  A solid easy drinking beer.
Tap @ Zoiglstube. Orange color, cloudy. malty flavor with some initial flowery hops. Hint of licorice. Bready. Hint of citrus. Almost medium bodied. Lovely zoigl, a bit low on aroma.
Cloudy orange-amber.  Fresh smelling and slightly herbal.  Very dry, appetizing.  Spicy-herbal hop character.  Very rounded with a firm, understated maltiness.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2011 At Posterer. Hazy orange with thick white head. Brisk hoppy nose. Great bread crust flavors (surprise!) and a nice dollop of marmalade. Dry finish. Very good beer. Re-rate, the smoothness, the luminescent orange, the sweet malts, the toasty bready character make this an accessible and supreme zoigl, still characteristically salty/minerally.

Draught at their tap. Good refreshing aroma, weak rough hoppiness and a little bread. Cloudy orange colour. Big stable rocky white head. The flavour has a refreshing hoppiness, not much flavour, medium bitterness, but very cleansing. Medium maltiness.

On tap (@Zum Posterer): Cloudy, deep golden, quite stable creamy off-white head with a little lace; moderate yeasty-fruity and quite spicy-hoppy nose; moderate bitter-sweet flavour, quite soft MF, light to medium bodied; smooth, lingering hoppy, a bit yeasty finish with a light tartness in the aftertaste. Good, not world-shaking............
